summary: Jose Miro Cardona was a prominent figure in the Cuban exile community, serving as a leader within the Cuban Revolutionary Council. The documents suggest his involvement in anti-Castro activities and his potential resignation from the Cuban Revolutionary Council due to perceived changes in U.S. policy toward Cuba. He communicated with Miguel Ydigoras-Fuentes, facilitated by Carlos Alejos, regarding anti-Fidel Castro activities. The documents highlight his role in the Cuban exile movement and his interactions with other key figures involved in efforts to overthrow the Castro regime.
significance: The documents suggest that Jose Miro Cardona was a key figure in the anti-Castro movement, which is relevant to the JFK assassination context because some theories suggest that anti-Castro groups may have been involved in the assassination due to President Kennedy's perceived insufficient support for their cause. His role as a leader within the Cuban Revolutionary Council and his connections to other anti-Castro figures make him a person of interest in understanding the dynamics of the Cuban exile community and their potential motivations.
